content:
• Friday, August 9, 2013
  • INSG

    Novatel Wireless continues to plummet

    • Novatel Wireless (NVTL -5.2%) fell again today, as the market continues digesting the company's Wednesday Q2 whiff. Shares dove 17.4% this week, but remain up 160% YTD.
    • Q3 guidance for revenue of $90M-100M and EPS of -$0.14 to -$0.02 was in-line with consensus. (CC)
    • Novatel has now missed analyst estimates the past 4 quarters (I, II, III, IV), but the fallen dot-com bubble darling has nonetheless been on a tear after plunging in 2012.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:21 PM
  • TWER

    Towerstream sells off on mediocre Q2 results

    • Towerstream (TWER -7.2%) dove after the company delivered so-so Q2 results.
    • ARPU increased 5% Y/Y to $740 (up for the fifth consecutive quarter). ARPU for new customers was up 34.2% Y/Y to $630, and up 1.6% Q/Q.
    • Rising wireless data demand in urban areas is expected to be a growth driver for the company. Towerstream is betting carriers will rely on its Wi-Fi offerings to address capacity needs.
    • Highlight: the company signed a long-term Wi-Fi lease agreement with a major cable operator in Q2. CEO Jeffrey Thompson: "Securing the first anchor tenant for our neutral host network ... validates our rent-based business model."
     
     
     
     
    | 8:02 PM
  • INO

    More on Inovio Pharmaceuticals earnings

    • Inovio Pharmaceuticals (NYSEMKT:INO) posts a mixed Q2, beating on revenue but coming up short on a per share basis as losses were greater than expected.
    • Total revenue rose Y/Y, primarily due to higher revenue recognized from its PATH Malaria Vaccine Initiative grant, its U.S. DoD Small Business Innovation Research Grant and its grant subcontract with the University of Pennsylvania.
    • Per share losses also increased however, primarily from a higher mark-to-market change in fair value of common stock warrants, as well as a decrease in the fair market value of its investment in its affiliated entity, VGX International.
    • Shares -12.5% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:24 PM | 9 Comments
  • PBR

    Petrobras swings to Q2 profit on higher fuel prices

    • Petrobras (NYSE:PBR) swings to a Q2 net profit of 6.2B Brazilian reais ($2.73M), above the BRL5.3B analyst consensus, as higher fuel prices reverse a year-ago loss.
    • EBITDA came in at BRL18.1B vs. BRL10.6B in the year-ago period.
    • Revenue rose to BRL73.6B, +8.2% Y/Y, as Brazil's domestic gasoline prices rose 2.3% and diesel prices gained 5.6%, according to the Agora brokerage.
    • Shares +2.2% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:06 PM | 4 Comments
  • DTLK

    Datalink claws back losses after pricing new offering

    • Datalink (DTLK +2.3%) clawed backed some of the week's losses after pricing the 3.3M share public offering (and 495K overallotment) it announced on Monday at $11/share. Shares nonetheless fell 11% on the week. (Prospectus)
    • The offering is set to close on Aug. 14.
    • With offering proceeds of $33.8M, a new $40M channel finance and revolving credit facility, and $23M in cash in hand, the stage has been set for CEO Paul Lidsky to continue Datalink's aggressive acquisition strategy.
    • The company previously acquired rival Stratech for $13.2M in cash and $23.1M in stock in Oct. 2012. Datalink is aiming for one acquisition every 12-18 months. (10Q)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:52 PM
  • WLT

    Coal stocks rally on improved Moody's outlook

    • Coal stocks (NYSEARCA:KOL) rallied today after Moody’s raised its coal industry outlook to stable from negative, saying business conditions have hit bottom and it doesn't expect industry fundamentals to deteriorate further over the next 12-18 months.
    • "Sustained natural gas prices will prop up demand for the thermal coal used in power production through mid-2014 to early 2015, while supply rationalization should help stabilize prices for metallurgical coal, which is used in steelmaking," the ratings agency says.
    • Surging today: WLT +13.7%, JRCC +11.8%, ANR +11.4%, ACI +8.6%, BTU +7.8%, CNX +4%, CLD +3.6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:44 PM | 8 Comments

  • After-hours top gainers/ Losers

    • After-hours top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: AGO +13%. CVT +12%. ASTX +5%. CADX +4%. AKS +3%.
    • After-hours top losers: BIOS -3%. ZOLT -2%. WWWW -2%. MNKD -2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:31 PM | 1 Comment

  • The week's ETF movers - Gainers / Losers

    • The week's ETF movers - Gainers: GDXJ +6.13%. KOL +3.76%. PSLV +3.69%. GDX +3.44%. SLV +3.35%.
    • ETF Losers: XHB -4.12%. UNG -3.56%. GAZ -3.07%. VNM -2.13%. EWY -2.10%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:17 PM | 1 Comment
  • MACK

    Merrimack Pharmaceuticals misses on Q2 EPS; moves up on back of SA blog

    • Merrimack Pharmaceuticals (MACK +10.4%) finishes higher today, despite posting a Q2 net loss of $0.31 per share, missing estimates by $0.03.
    • Collaboration revenues were $12.063M , also down versus a year ago.
    • Perhaps today's strength can be attributed to an upbeat SA post reporting Tekla Capital Management has bought 537,600 shares since the beginning of the year, 353,400 shares in Q2 alone.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:33 PM
  • BGMD

    BG Medical cut to Neutral at Baird; shares finish lower

    • BG Medical (OTC:BGMD -13.4%) finishes the day markedly lower after Baird cut the shares to Neutral this morning and reduced its price target to $1 from $3.
    • The downgrade follows the company's Q2 earnings report released Thursday, showing that revenue grew 62% Y/Y, but missed expectations.
    • The firm says new management is taking the appropriate actions to refocus the company on better near-term opportunities, but H2 looks to be well below consensus, as commercial traction has been slow, near-term opportunities are heavily dependent on external parties, and financial flexibility becomes more limited.
    • Baird suggests moving to the sidelines, and waiting for signs that a more meaningful revenue ramp is materializing.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:08 PM
  • ARCB

    Arkansas Best jumps after Q2 results

    • Shares of Arkansas Best (ABFS +16.6%) are having a banner day on the heels of the company's Q2 report.
    • Revenue was up 13% Y/Y during the period to $576.9M, beating estimates.
    • Q2 EPS of $0.18 looks optically worse than the $0.44/ share profit the company posted in Q2 2012. However, a tax benefit was largely responsible for last year's Q2 EPS figure. Strip that out and add back a $0.05/ share charge associated with the Panther acquisition and you get $0.18, exactly the same as this quarter's figure. (PR)
    • The company notes that the ratification of the ABF National Master Freight Agreement is a "major step toward returning the company to consistent profitability." (previous)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:54 PM
  • GNVC

    GenVec votes to dissolve company

    • GenVec (GNVC -20%) tanks after disclosing that it's unanimously agreed that dissolving the firm was in its best interests, concluding any of the other proposed transactions were at best, "extremely risky."
    • The resolution still requires shareholder approval before being forwarded to the Delaware Secretary of State.
    • The company estimates it will incur about $311,785 in costs as a result of employee layoffs.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:42 PM
  • AIRM

    Air Methods surges 14% as Q2 miss attributed to weather

    • Although Air Methods' (AIRM +14.5%) Q2 results missed analyst estimates, Oppenheimer says "all indications point to a very strong rebound in [H2], as lower maintenance, improved weather, a rebound in payor mix and stronger pricing should act as catalysts going forward."
    • AIRM attributes decreases in June and July flight volumes to higher weather cancellations, but Q2 brought a return to growth in net revenue per patient transport, while days' sales outstanding decreased from 128 days as of March 31 to 99 days as of June 30.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:31 PM | 1 Comment
  • PMC

    Pharmerica charged by Justice Department for violating Controlled Substances Act; filing false Medicare claims

    • The Justice Department has filed suit against PharMerica (PMC -6%) claiming it violated the False Claims Act and the Controlled Substances Act by dispensing controlled drugs without valid prescriptions and causing claims for illegally dispensed drugs to be submitted to the Medicare program.
    • The complaint alleges that PMC routinely dispensed Schedule II controlled drugs in non-emergency situations without first obtaining a written prescription from a treating physician, then knowingly submitted false claims to Medicare for the improperly dispensed Schedule II drugs.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:30 PM
  • GTIV

    Amedisys news propels Gentiva Health sharply higher

    • News that KKR has taken an 8.5% stake in Amedisys looks to be fueling a rally in shares of competitor Gentiva Health Systems (GTIV +17.3%). The stock has traded sharply higher throughout the session.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:20 PM
  • CZR

    Caesars Entertainment selling Macau property

    • Caesars Entertainment (CZR +4.3%) hits a 52-week high after disclosing it is selling its property in Macau to Asian developer Pearl Dynasty for $438M.
    • The sale price is well shy of the $578M corporate predecessor Harrah's paid for the property in 2007, but CZR was unable to secure a license to build a casino on the property.
    • CZR also has been enjoying a boost on talk that Nevada and New Jersey are working on an online gambling compact, a potential step closer to legal, national online gaming.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:16 PM
  • CLF

    Global cyclicals extend gains on Chinese industrial growth

    • Cliffs Natural Resources (CLF +10.6%) and other heavy global cyclical stocks are among the day's strongest performers, adding to yesterday's gains sparked by Chinese industrial growth.
    • BTU +8.1%, RIO +6%, BHP +3.1%, X +4.9%, MT +6.2%, NUE +4.5%, VALE +5.8% FCX +3.4%, SCCO +4%, JOY +3.4%, CAT +0.8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:59 PM | 2 Comments
  • NDLS

    Noodles shares slip after underwhelming forecast

    • Noodles & Co.'s (NDLS -9.9%) first results since debuting on the market beat estimates but the company eked out only a small profit, which slumped 97% Y/Y, weighed by expenses tied to the IPO.
    • NDLS guided FY 2013 EPS to $0.39-$0.41 vs. $0.31 in 2012, in-line with analysts' estimates of $0.40 but investors apparently expected more; expectations of a 3% rise in sales at established restaurants would be a slowdown from Q2's 4.4% gain.
    • Stifel Nicolaus says investors have overvalued NDLS growth prospects; the firm expects shares to trade more in line with the market over the next year.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:42 PM
  • YONG

    Yongye International jumps on Q2 reuslts

    • Shares of Yongye International (YONG +9.9%) are among today's winners after the Chinese agricultural nutrient company reported Q2 results.
    • Revenue for the period was $301.3M, up nearly 70% from Q2 2012.
    • Q2 adjusted EPS came in at $1.51, which looks pretty good compared to $0.74/ share in the same period last year.
    • No decision has been made on a response to a going private proposal.
    • Outlook: FY13 total shipments of $650-680M. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:36 PM
  • GPS

    Gap -3% after disappointing same-store sales, analyst downgrade

    • Investors focus on Gap's (GPS -2.9%) below-consensus 1% increase in July same-store sales rather than upside Q2 guidance, sending shares sharply lower.
    • Analysts generally are more positive than the market; Janney blames sputtering sales on difficult comparisons, remains encouraged by solid traffic trends across all divisions, and expects sustainable positive comps going forward.
    • Even a downgrade to Neutral at Susquehanna is based entirely on valuation; the firm says Q2 was "another well executed quarter" and "applaud[s] management’s execution of the business, distribution of excess cash to shareholders and focus on building an omni-channel global presence."
     
     
     
     
    | 2:22 PM
  • CFN

    Carefusion drifts lower on an FQ4 earnings miss

    • CareFusion (CFN -0.4%) dips into the red today after its FQ4 missed estimates across the board.
    • Net earnings increased 14% Y/Y as margins improved and overhead expenses decreased.
    • Procedural-solutions segment revenue jumped 7.2% to $311M, with gains across all business lines, but medical-systems revenue fell 12% over the same period to $592M.
    • For the new year, the company sees its EPS coming in between $2.30 to $2.40 on revenue growth of 1% to 4%, bracketing Street estimates of $2.36 per share and revenue growth of 3%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:15 PM
  • MNST

    Goldman isn't afraid of the Monster after "choppy" quarter

    • Goldman is still positive on Buy-rated Monster Beverage (MNST +1.9%) following a Q2 miss, and apparently so are investors as the stock trades higher after showing some weakness in Thursday's post-session.
    • Analyst Judy Hong says the "core tenets" of the company's story (U.S. sales recovery, international growth, higher international profits) remain largely intact.
    • Hong got some clarity from management on the conference call regarding the pipe lap in Japan and excluding that, she thinks "underlying sales are running close to +10%."
    • Goldman's price target is $70.
    • Read Hong's Q&A with management on the CC transcript
    • Earnings summary
     
     
     
     
    | 2:14 PM
  • ENTR

    Entropic higher after CEO discloses 10K-share purchase

    • Entropic (ENTR +3.3%) CEO Patrick Henry discloses he bought 10K shares on Thursday at $3.67. (Form 4)
    • The vote of confidence comes with Entropic shares close to multi-year lows thanks to the dismal Q3 guidance provided by the chipmaker last week.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:12 PM
  • ECOM

    ChannelAdvisor up second day in a row after Q2 beat

    • ChannelAdvisor (ECOM +4.3%) is up for the second consecutive day after the company handily beat Q2 estimates, and provided strong full-year guidance. The stock is up 25% since Wednesday, and 77% from its May IPO price of $14.
    • Previous: ChannelAdvisor reported strong same-store sales growth for clients selling via Amazon and eBay in June, and also did so for the 2 previous months.
    •  On deck: July client same-store sales results
     
     
     
     
    | 2:06 PM
  • NOAH

    Noah skyrockets after raising guidance

    • Noah Holdings (NOAH +25.3%) shares skyrocket after the Chinese money manager lifted its full-year earnings outlook, saying business has grown faster than expected.
    • NOAH raised net income guidance by ~50% to $50M-$55M from $33M-$37M and now anticipates 86-105% Y/Y growth, driven mostly by its Gopher asset management business.
    • Oppenheimer upgrades shares to Outperform with an $18 price target, as robust Gopher growth more than offsets the uncertainties at the traditional distribution business.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:05 PM
  • ZOLT

    Zoltek rumored to have receive takeover approach

    • Shares of Zoltek (ZOLT -1.2%) get volatile on the back of a Financial Times report saying the carbon fiber composite maker is rumored to have received takeover approaches at around $22 per share, which would value the company at about $800M.
    • Quinpario Acquisition Corp., a blank check acquisition firm, coincidentally priced its IPO at $10 and begins trading on the Nasdaq Exchange today under the symbol "QPACU," is the leading suitor.
    • In March, Quinpario had an offer rejected to buy Zoltek for a price in the mid teens.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:57 PM
  • NKTR

    Nektar and AstraZeneca amend naloxegol agreement

    • Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR +12.1%) is flying high today after posting a Q2 loss that wasn't as wide as analysts expected.
    • Certainly worth a look is an 8-K filed yesterday which amends the terms of NKTR's naloxegol license agreement with AstraZeneca (AZN +0.1%).
    • AZN will submit an NDA to the FDA and an MAA to the EMA next month. Acceptance of the NDA entitles NKTR to a $70M milestone payment within five days. Acceptance of the MAA wins NKTR $25M.
    • If the FDA does not require a pre-approval CV study, NKTR is eligible for another $35M. However, if the regulator does require a CV study, AZN can terminate the agreement, in which case NKTR will have to pay $70M plus accrued interest in four installments.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:48 PM
  • AVG

    AVG slumps following block trade

    • AVG (AVG -4.5%) is down to $21.56 after a 3.5M-share block trade was carried out this morning at $21.75, courtesy of Morgan Stanley.
    • Shares dove a week ago on account of the soft Q3 guidance provided with the company's Q2 results, but had largely recouped their losses going into today.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:45 PM
  • AGO

    Assured Guaranty moves higher against a mixed Q2 report

    • Assured Guaranty (AGO +3.5%) moves up despite posting a Q2 miss on its EPS late yesterday.
    • Net profit fell 42% Y/Y as the bond insurer reported a lower fair-value gain and a decrease in net earned premiums.
    • The latest period included just $28M in non-credit unrealized fair value gains on credit derivatives, compared with a $160M fair-value gain in the year-ago quarter.
    • Net investment slipped 7.9% to $93M.
    • Net premiums earned fell 26% to $163M.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:41 PM
  • QLIK

    Qlik, Tibco rally in sympathy with Tableau

    • Qlik (QLIK +3.9%) and Tibco (TIBX +1.5%) are trading higher after analytics/data visualization software rival Tableau (DATA +13.5%) soundly beats Q2 estimates, reports strong deal activity, and issues above-consensus Q3/2013 guidance.
    • UBS' Brent Thill is raising his Tableau PT to $75 from $65. He notes Tableau's 1.5K new customers top the 1K Qlik reported for Q2, and argues the size of Microsoft's Excel installed base (~1B users) "proves [Tableau] has a long way to go" in its "multi-year journey to disrupt the traditional [business intelligence software] space
    • Qlik sold off following its July 25 Q2 report, but subsequently rebounded, and is making new 52-week highs today.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:34 PM
  • JCP

    J.C. Penney Chairman issues statement on Ackman letter

    • J.C. Penney's (JCP -6.3%) Chairman issues a statement in response to Bill Ackman's second letter to the board. Highlights are below.
    • The board is focused on stabilizing and rejuvenating the business.
    • CEO search is being conducted at an appropriate pace.
    • Ackman's statements are "inaccurate and counterproductive."
    • Update 1:40: Ackman responds to JCP's Chairman, telling CNBC's Scott Wapner that Pershing Square's letter is "entirely accurate" and saying he looks forward to meeting with the "entire board."
     
     
     
     
    | 1:33 PM | 1 Comment
  • PGNX

    Progenix slips on mixed Q2, misses on revenue

    • Progenix Pharmaceuticals (PGNX -1.2%) slips after reporting a mixed Q2, coming in-line on a per share basis but missing on revenue.
    • Royalty income was $1.2M compared to $1.6M in Q212, largely based on net sales of Relistor.
    • Relistor global net sales increased 2% Q/Q, but fell by 27% Y/Y.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:22 PM
  • JNPR

    Juniper discloses SEC/DOJ bribery investigations, shares fall

    • In its Q2 10-Q, Juniper (JNPR -5%) discloses the SEC and DOJ are "conducting investigations into possible violations by the Company of the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act."
    • Juniper says it's cooperating. However, a spokesman adds the company "can't predict the scope or duration" of the probes.
    • IBM and Microsoft are contending with similar investigations.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:11 PM
  • BB

    BlackBerry pares gains a bit; analysts skeptical buyout will happen

    • Though still up sharply, BlackBerry (BBRY +6.4%) is below its premarket highs, as analysts question the odds the company will actually be taken private and/or doubt a major premium will be paid.
    • BGC: "Never say never but my read on this is this is just talk. ... You have to be highly skeptical of anonymous sources when there are no sources of capital."
    • MKM: "If it were to happen, however, we think it’s more likely to be a take-under than a deal with a meaningful premium."
    • Wells Fargo argues BlackBerry doesn't need to go private if it's willing to adjust its cost structure "to the reality of being a much-smaller revenue-generating entity." The firm points out BlackBerry spent 18.8% of its revenue on SG&A over the last 4 quarters (compared with 13.2% of Nokia's phone unit and 6.3% for Apple), and 12.9% on R&D (Nokia's phone unit was at 11.3%, and Apple at 2.5%).
    • Previous: BlackBerry reportedly open to going private
     
     
     
     
    | 1:01 PM | 8 Comments
  • HZNP

    Horizon Pharma slides despite posting a solid Q2

    • Horizon Pharma (HZNP -5%) slips today, despite reporting a solid Q2.
    • Gross and net sales rose 64% and 34% respectively Q/Q.
    • Cash and cash equivalents as of June 30 total $69.3M, versus $81.1M at the end of March.
    • Total DUEXIS pills dispensed in Q2 increased 9.3% versus Q1, as a result of longer initial prescriptions and a 3.7% Q/Q increase in refill rates.
    • Gross-to-net sales deduction for DUEXIS was 33.1% versus 20.6% in Q1.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:55 PM
  • MHRCQ

    Magnum Hunter eyes more sales, but shares slump

    • Magnum Hunter (MHR -3.1%) says sales of non-core assets are set to be announced in the near future, but shares are lower after Q2 earnings and revenues miss expectations (conference call).
    • A big jump in expenses sent MHR to a $37.7M Q2 operating loss, but gains on disposals allowed it post a $165.4M net profit vs. a $14.5M loss a year ago.
    • Production rose 23% Y/Y on increased drilling of shale plays but was adversely impacted by shut-ins in the Appalachian division due to pipeline and liquid handling issues relating to MHR's midstream gathering facilities.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:52 PM

  • Midday top 10 gainers / Losers

    • Midday top 10 gainers: PTIX +101%. BOSC +46%. GBR +29%. UBNT +27%. NOAH +26%. NPSP +24%. GERN +22%. OTCPK:IFNY +22%. AMED +19%. OTC:RITT +19%.
    •  Losers: MRGE -44%. CNYD -27%. DNDN -24%. YRCW -17%. CRMB -16%. EDS -15%. SLTC -15%. BIOL -15%. NPTN -14%. CPST -13%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:46 PM
  • NPTN

    NeoPhotonics slumps on lowered guidance

    • NeoPhotonics (NPTN -13.6%) shares are slumping after the company provided underwhelming Q3 guidance to go with its Q2 beat.
    • Revenue guidance of $72M-78M is below a consensus of $83.7M. EPS guidance of -$0.14 to -$0.04 is below a consensus of $0.05. (8-K).
    • The numbers come shortly after telecom optical component rival Finisar raised its July quarter guidance, and saw its shares take off in response. However, Finisar's guidance hike had more to do with datacom, rather than telecom, component sales.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:43 PM
  • VALE

    Vale extends gains, reaps praise for cost-cutting focus

    • Vale (VALE +5%) shares extend strong gains following the Brazilian miner's Q2 results, which look surprisingly strong once a $2.8B currency hit is removed, and positive comments about China’s demand for iron ore.
    • Nomura says Vale’s strategy of focusing on the development of core projects while lowering its cost structure is starting to show favorable results, which should allow the leverage of production growth finally set to come online starting in H2.
    • The firm sees Vale earning "significant" cash, estimating 2014 and 2015 free cash flow yields at 3% and 4% respectively.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:32 PM | 1 Comment
  • DE

    Deere hit by a couple more downgrades on weak macro-outlook

    • Deere (DE -1.8%) slips on a couple of downgrades today, one from ISI to Neutral and another from UBS to Sell.
    • UBS says it expects stock performance to mirror weakness in corn prices, which will pressure demand for agricultural equipment in the coming year.
    • FY14 earnings are likely to decline, as farmers react to lower cash receipts and farm income.
    • The moves follow a similiar downgrade earlier this week from William Blair, who said farm-equipment markets will be challenged over the next couple of years as assets including corn, farmland and used equipment fall in value.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:18 PM
  • ROAN

    Goldman sees buy-the-dip opportunity in Linn Energy, LinnCo

    • Goldman Sachs sees the two-day 10% drop in Linn Energy (LINE -5.3%) following Q2 results as a buy-the-dip opportunity, maintaining Buy recommendations on LINE and LinnCo (LNCO -6.7%) with respective $34 and $35 price targets.
    • Goldman believes LINE was prudent in pulling back on plans for a distribution increase given uncertainties around the Berry Petroleum (BRY -1.2%) acquisition and coverage currently running below 1x.
    • The firm reiterates concerns over LINE's hedge accounting and maintenance capital are overblown.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:17 PM | 7 Comments
  • BKNG

    $1,000+ PTs assigned to Priceline following Q2 beat

    • Analysts are rushing to give Priceline (PCLN +4.6%) $1,000+ PTs in the wake of the online travel giant's Q2 beat and healthy guidance.
    • Cantor ($1,050) thinks Priceline not only performed well internationally, but "also likely gained ground in the US, benefiting from increased TV ads and Expedia's mis-execution on TripAdvisor." It sees Priceline's "best-in-class hotel inventory" and Kayak's international expansion fueling additional share gains.
    • Deutsche ($1,120) thinks Priceline's EBITDA margin (pressured lately by heavy ad spend) could be roughly flat Y/Y in Q3, a notable improvement from recent quarters.
    • Evercore ($1,100) declares Booking.com "still enjoys the highest marketing efficiency in the industry." Its PT is based on a lofty multiple of 24x 2014E adjusted EPS.
    • Priceline noted on its CC Booking.com now lists 330K+ hotels/accomodations, +40% Y/Y. The company attributed its 410 bps Y/Y op. margin drop to lower (online) ad ROIs, mix shifts, and growing offline ad spend for Kayak and Booking.com.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:09 PM | 1 Comment
  • SQNM

    Sequenom spikes higher

    • Sequenom (SQNM +5%) pops on chatter that the company will be allowed to pursue a ban of a certain pre-natal test.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:05 PM | 1 Comment
  • RIG

    Transocean cut to Neutral at Global Hunter, shares slip

    • Transocean (RIG -1.9%) is downgraded to Neutral from Buy with a $51 price target, down from $64, at Global Hunter, which notes a subdued outlook for both deepwater and midwater rigs.
    • The firm says it nailed its forecast for revenue and operating expense, but its expectation for RIG to lower cost guidance through year-end and discuss potential further savings in 2014 did not occur.
    • In addition to the subdued rig outlook, RIG indicated that idle time in the future is likely, which generally leads to an erosion in rates.
    • Initial reaction to RIG's largely in-line Q2 had been more moderate, as Jefferies and Stephens reiterated Hold/Neutral ratings.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:56 AM | 2 Comments
  • AMED

    Amedisys soars on KKR stake

    • Shares of Amedisys (AMED +21.8%) are up sharply on the session as KKR reveals a new 8.5% stake in the company. (13D)
    • CRT takes the shares to Fairly Valued from Sell. (details)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:55 AM
  • EBIX

    Ebix slumps following mixed Q2 results

    • Embattled Ebix (EBIX -8%) is selling off after slightly beating Q2 EPS estimates, and missing revenue estimates by $1M.
    • Ebix posted 7% Y/Y sales growth in Q2, a slowdown from Q1's 20%.
    • Op. margin was 37.8%, +110 bps Q/Q and +110 bps Y/Y, in spite of rising legal costs.
    • Only $2.5M was spent on buybacks. Ebix has $102.9M remaining under its buyback authorization. $5.6M was spent to pay down bank debt; net debt now stands at $30.8M.
    • Ebix is being investigated the SEC and the Atlanta U.S. Attorney's office, and reportedly by the FBI. Shares crashed on Tuesday thanks to Bloomberg's FBI report, but subsequently recouped a majority of their losses.
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 11:37 AM
  • CORT

  • WMGI

    Wright Medical slides after FDA issues not-approvable letter for its Augment Bone Graft

    • Wright Medical Group (WMGI -8.3%) takes a hit today after the FDA issues a "not-approvable letter" for its Augment Bone Graft, noting problems with the clinical study.
    • The device, which is designed as an alternative to autograft in orthopedic surgeries, involves the use of tissue from another part of a patient's body.
    • The agency said that the study enrolled people who were predominantly low risk, and may not have needed the procedures.
    • Additionally, it was unsure whether a similar result might have been achieved without any graft material.
    • It concluded that it may be necessary to perform a new clinical study, with a well-defined high-risk population.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:42 AM
